figgy.title: Update linked resource factory

comments.body: `*Factory.new(resource:).new` was a pattern I've followed based upon what I had observed elsewhere in the codebase (please see https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/master/app/change_set_persisters/change_set_persister.rb#L33).  I fully support this being refactored into a single class method invocation where appropriate.

That's interesting. I agree with this ticket, but I also don't want to change the pattern in ChangeSetPersister handlers. I'll have to reflect on that. I think it's because the handlers were added after the fact and are there to respond to a duck typing that already existed?

In the change set persister the factories are created in one place and used in another. I think that's when it's appropriate to use a factory class (*Factory). Here, I checked the invocations before writing this ticket, and that's not done. Moving the factory from its own class to a `for` method on the `LinkedResource` class would help differentiate the use case.

Agreed. Also, I like the factory class when you're dependency injecting multiple factories and need some extra parameter to be available. When you're just abstracting away the polymorphism the method pattern is easier to look at.

figgy.title: Slug generation for Geo documents without a `held_by` fails.

comments.body:
This was not supposed to happen. I'm guessing that this occurred before `held_by` was assigned a default value.

https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/master/app/change_sets/concerns/geo_change_set_properties.rb#L9

I'll search for nil values and replace them.
This affected 18 raster resources and 2 vector resources. These were fixed and this should no longer be an problem.

figgy.title: Some child raster resources have same ARK id as parent scanned map
Contributor Role for Ephemera Projects

comments.body: What are the implications of implementing without worrying about solr discovery? The contributor will be able to search and will only see public results, and not necessarily the results from the project they are working on?

> What are the implications of implementing without worrying about solr discovery? The contributor will be able to search and will only see public results, and not necessarily the results from the project they are working on?

Yes. We're assuming they're not going to use the search box.

Given the role of service provider these contributors will be receiving training from us on how to use Figgy.  I think it's fine if the search functionality doesn't work as you might expect, since they don't need it to do the metadata entry and ingest work we're hiring them for.

comments.body: @kellybolding We're reviewing tickets, can you confirm that this is still something you want?
I could still see it being helpful, but I don’t see this as essential at this point. I would say making sure we can ingest other formats (video) is a much higher priority.
@kellybolding Thanks! Do you want us to keep this ticket around, or should we close it and see if it comes up again in the future?
I’m ok with closing it and seeing if it comes up again (unless you have some sort of workflow in place for keeping track of “someday maybe” tickets). ☺
@kellybolding We do have that workflow! I'll put it in place there.

pulfa.title: Request edit of strict schema to display all local, controlled attribute values

comments.body:
Oh, now I understand. This doesn’t involve an edit to the schema file; rather, it requires a change to how processors set up their preferences on their machines. It looks like we can edit the cc_config file. I’ll investigate.

https://www.oxygenxml.com/doc/versions/21.1/ug-editor/topics/streamline-with-content-completion.html#streamline-with-content-completion
https://www.oxygenxml.com/doc/versions/21.1/ug-editor/topics/configuring-content-completion-proposals.html


Regine Heberlein
Library IT Data Analyst
609-258-6156
heberlei@princeton.edu


From: faithc <notifications@github.com>
Reply-To: pulibrary/pulfa <reply@reply.github.com>
Date: Monday, September 30, 2019 at 3:04 PM
To: pulibrary/pulfa <pulfa@noreply.github.com>
Cc: "Regine I. Heberlein" <heberlei@Princeton.EDU>, Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [pulibrary/pulfa] Request edit of strict schema to display all local, controlled attribute values (#333)


unitid @ type “itemnumber” or “accessionnumber”. These values show up when a user validates a file if there is an error; but they don't display in a pop-up window for users to select at the time of encoding as attribute values do via the EAD schema, for instance, unitdate @ type "inclusive" and "bulk." Does that make sense?

pulfa.title: Title proper should display text string rather than normalized dates
extent for Mudd files: digital files don't compute correctly

comments.body: Hi @regineheberlein I tested the new normalizer on AC122. The digitalfiles attribution was not overridden but the unit='websites' was converted to an item. At the collection level, the linear footage extent was taken out and the total number of digital files were in an exponential number (2.46921846E8 digitalfiles). At lower levels with less files, the digital extent looks just fine.

Thanks @vjohnson0707<mailto:notifications@github.com>, I’ll check it out!

Regine Heberlein
Library IT Data Analyst
609-258-6156
heberlei@princeton.edu


From: vjohnson0707 <notifications@github.com>

Subject: Re: [pulibrary/pulfa] extent for Mudd files: digital files don't compute correctly (#307)


Hi @regineheberlein<https://github.com/regineheberlein> I tested the new normalizer on AC122. The digitalfiles attribution was not overridden but the unit='websites' was converted to an item. At the collection level, the linear footage extent was taken out and the total number of digital files were in an exponential number (2.46921846E8 digitalfiles). At lower levels with less files, the digital extent looks just fine.
